I have already answered a similar question to this one: Jeremy Hughes's answer to Does sound behave like light in special relativity?, but I can try to look at it from a different perspective. We can look at the physical side where waves and light both undergo the phenomena of refraction, diffraction, reflection, etc, but we would also have to consider the fact that light is known to interact with matter in a particle like manner, such as in the Photoelectric Effect and the Compton/Inverse Compton Effect (I would include Mossbauer Effect here also, but this is not an accepted depiction of light acting as a particle, since it is independent of intensity.) Newton himself preferred a particle model for light since light does not diffract as much as classical waves. This information can be found with a general internet search. In the context of Relativity, it is of the utmost importance to understand that the classical understanding of wave motion and the second postulate share many similarities, BUT being aware of their major differences is absolutely crucial too. Understanding the related characteristics between light and classical waves is not only important for visualizing and applying the second postulate in the correct way, but also their differences can make us aware of when we can’t apply a particular reasoning to a problem (thought experiment) because it violates the second postulate by making use of a wave model. The second postulate, though it shares some characteristics with a wave model is most definitely not a wave model. Light shares with waves the characteristic that a relative speed is impossible by motion of a source. What is NOT shared is that a relative speed of light is impossible by the second postulate, but a relative speed of a wave is possible through motion of an observer relative to a medium through which a wave propagates. The impossibility of a relative speed of light due to motion of an observer negates the possibility of a medium (Ether), which is another difference between the two theories. There is one exception, and one exception only, whereby light will behave like a wave and have a relative speed. But this point is crucial: this is only possible from the reference frame, and perspective, of an observer with relative motion to another observer or object. A relative speed of light is impossible in an observer’s OWN frame of reference, but an observer in motion relative to this observer will have a relative speed to the same light, albeit ALWAYS lower than the speed of light. Einstein made this error in his description of the Relativity of Simultaneity thought experiment. He projected the results from one frame into the other frame in relative motion in his justification of relative time. And this error is perpetuated by those who do not realize when an observer can have a relative motion to light (across frames), and when they can not (own frame), using “hastening” of an observer in its own frame to explain Special Relativity. Awareness of this distinguishing difference between waves and light is more crucial than understanding what they share. Using the shared properties of light and waves, leads to the right answer, and this is best accomplished by always considering an observer at rest in its own frame (you always should, because you have to), with a source in motion relative to the observer. Using what they don’t share leads to errors such as thinking time is actually relative (not just measurement) and confusion among those trying to learn the second postulate and apply it correctly. Light is NOT a wave, but they are similar. It might be hard to distinguish between a Canadian and American at first glance, but once you get into their deeper nuances, we can easily distinguish the two and realize that they are not exactly the same. The same could be said with many Europeans until we hear them speak, or get a chance to watch their mannerisms - a simple picture would not be enough. Brad Pitt said that “we spend 95% of our time fighting about the 5% that makes us different”, which I agree is pointless in some ways in terms of politics, but sometimes those 5% differences are crucial. Whether the stats are the same for shared characteristics between a wave and light, I don’t know, but the crucial difference between the two must be understood.

However, the Doppler effect will make the wave blue shifted for the observers that are in the direction the source was moving and red shifted for the observers located in the direction where the source was moving away.If a source can move faster than the wave propagation speed, the frequencies all concentrate creating a sharp white noise called sonic boom for sound waves and “Cherenkow radiation” for electromagnetic waves.There is many more common points but I wanted to highlight some of the most important and rarely mentioned characteristics. Two major differences: One is about 1 million times faster than the other (the slower one involve mechanical motion of atoms/molecules, the other involve electrons only which are 1836 times lighter ; not enough to explain the 1 million speed ratio, but half way there on a log scale)The shape is different : the mechanical waves is a growing sphere, the other a transverse wave like on a guitar stringRadio waves can be produced with arbitrary intensity. Whichever radio station has more money can use a bigger vacuum tube operating at higher voltage to produce higher power radio waves. However, somewhere between 100 ghz and 100 thz, we loose that capacity to modulate arbitrary wave intensity. When reaching the visible light frequency range, we can only produce “particle” instead of traditional “waves”. The only way to get a monochromatic light more intense than another is increasing the number of photons per second. Each photon start travelling in straight line from the source. Their physical length is one wavelength and the physical height (the peak to peak) is probably a ratio of the wavelength. Both sound (mechanical) waves and electromagnetic waves (in the visible light range and higher) follow the inverse square root law for intensity versus distance from the source (at twice the distance, the intensity decrease 4 times) but for different reason. In one case, the spherical wave simply decrease in intensity. In the other case, it is the number of particle reaching target that decrease. Each photon remain the same intensity no matter the distance or time since its emission.

They are both waves, so yes. Electromagnetic waves are obviously waves made up of an electric field that is oscillating and a magnetic field that is oscillating. One unique characteristic it has is that it doesn't need a medium to travel in (it can travel through space). Sound on the other hand is a vibrational wave. That is, it travels by vibrating through some medium. When you yell on earth, you are vibrating air molecules which in turn continue to vibrate the next air molecules, and that's how sound travels. Yell in space and nothing happens. Other than the fact that they are both waves, and share common wave properties (diffraction, reflection, etc) they aren't very related.
